name: Istrolid
description: In Istrolid you design your own unique spaceships from a large number of parts to fit your strategy and play style. With no set units or factions you are free to create a fleet where each ship has its own balanced strengths and weaknesses, from basic fighters and bombers to hulking battleships and speedy destroyers.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows 7 Processor: 32-64bit Memory: 1 GB RAM

reviews.review_text: Very great game! Here's a list of my pros and cons:  Pros: +Extensive Campaign where you feel like you definitely are progressing +You can program your own AI for your fleet and let them fight for you! +Building whatever type of spacecraft you desire +Limitless combinations +Every weapon and part seems to have a place where it shines, and also can be countered +Multiplayer +Ability to save many of your designs on a little spreadsheet +Completely free +No micro-transactions at all  Cons: -A cap to how large you can build your spacecraft (but this is most likely here for a reason) -Sometimes laggy during multiplayer (only 3-4 games out of the several games I've played)
There aren't many good truly ''free'' most of them are just these ''free2play'' pay2progress or pay2win games or just a grindfest, but this game is a different story.

Another issue I have is the lack of 2v2 and 3v3 servers today there were only two 3v3 servers but one crashed and there was only one 2v2 and one 3v3. Istrolid is one of the best free games I have ever played. It is a Space RTS where you pit your custom made fleet against anothers. Balance a fleet of fighters, Anti-missile, artilary, cruisers, dreadnaughts, anything in between and more as you design each ship yourself. What truely sets it apart is the ability to give ships their own ai. Not only design each ship, but design how it fights allowing you to focus on other things.  Pros: -Very open but balanced ship creation,  -Every item has pros and cons that actually carry meaningful weight. -Plenty of players and lobbies -Infinite strategies to try -Easy ai design for the less programming savvy -Simple, but attractive graphics -Simple gameplay that allows simple to advanced strategies for all players. -Can play against dozens of unique AI fleets instead of other players. -Can play with teams upto 3, can be mixed with AI as well.   Cons: -Nothing forces a player to finish a game, making some matches anti-climatic. -Slighty buggy here and there, nothing game breaking. -Over simplified ai design hinders those who want more depth in their ai. -Map backgrounds are simple and a little bare. -One game type. -your statistics aren't tracked for online play. -The only restriction in ship creation is that it has to costs under $1000.   How a Match looks like: You start with $2000 to spawn the ships you want(or let the ai you made do that). Your goal is to capture every point on the map. Over time each point you own gives you more money to buy more ships. Mix defensive giants, small fighters, long range beams, artillary, lasers, support ships, and others to over come your opponent and capture the points. It can be very fast paced, or slowed paced depending on strategies. Ive had half hour matches, and others that lasted a few seconds.   Overall: 9/10  Simple but diverse game that leaves you tweaking your strategies for hours. The few minor nitpicks should not stop you from trying the game out.

Okay. So I downloded this game expecting it to be a customize-a-ship-and-then-kill-people type game. BOY HOW WAS I WRONG.   Istrolid is a Spaceship building simulator where you create spaceships in a customization menu, set up different spaceship troop setups, and then fight against an AI, 1 person, or multiple people on online servers in a king of the hill type arena with randomely generated maps every time.   With each ship you have to manage things like energy, energy consumption, speed, turning speed, and more while staying under a budget maximum of 1000 per ship. One unique feature I thought was cool was that the parts you use are completely free, but it only costs you when you go into battle. The more money spent, the stronger and more useful it (Likely) is, but it will eat up cash faster.    If you dont want to practice with another player, then there are tons of bots to fight against each with a different tactic (Mine being attaching bombs to fast ships and then spawning 50 of them since they are so cheap to buy).   Another thing, this game is free. Not free to play, FREE. As in no microtransactions.   All I can say is if your into massive customization or RTS's, this might be the game for you.

A very fun and intresting game. Completely free, and the ability to build your own ship is quite nice.  Plus, the ship-building has little constraints, so even with a few parts, you can build a lot of different ships.  Though, some things I found where a bit lacking are 1. Difficulty of the singleplayer campaign could be tweaked a bit. Some are can be a bit frustraiting with enemy ships that are much better than yours, and others can be beaten literally within ten seconds by spamming dozens of tiny 50$ fighters. 2. Fighting the AI can be a bit annoying, because they are so much more manuverable. Currently, the only command you can do is setting a 'rally point' where ships will go to when created, and telling a ship to move to a certain place. Your ships follow your directions to the letter, and won't even defend itself while moving if a enemy ship is following it from the back and shooting it to peices.  Moving your ships to more than one place at a time is more or less imposible. Dodging enemy fire or manuvering around them is only possible if you neglect your other ships.  The enemy? They easily move multiple ships to multiple places with ease. While you're telling each ship to go to each 'capture point' individually, the enemy will already have spawned ships that move to said points the moment they are made. Enemy ships will chose to run or fight your ships, and the light, speedy ships will run circles around your ships while they spin in place trying to hit the half-dozen tiny ships making loops everywhere. If you try to do this, you'll most likely lose all the ships. Enemy (non-combat)ships can hover around your ships and stay out of the range of your guns(or try anyways). Your ships will happily sit and get blown to peices by artillery if you don't tell them to move  An AI for your ships to tell them to run/fight/doge/etc would be nice.

Istrolid is a game about building and managing a fleet of ships against your openents. When you first play you have two options. singleplayer and multiplayer.  In single player you battle the A.I for controll of the galaxy and will start off with only a limited verierty of parts to use in building. But as you progress you will unlock new ones to aid you in battle. In multipalyer you fight other people and their fleets. All parts are unlocked and you can build whaterver you want. The battles can be 1v1 or team based. The building of the ships is very well done as you are given many different parts for different types of ships. This allows for a wide array of varying playstyles and adds to replayability. If you want you can even give your ships an custom A.I so you don't have to worry about micromanaging your fleet.  I highly recomend this game as its free, well balenced and best of all there are no microtransactions.
